before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"3bal6","text":"The RStudio program must be installed on the computer. If it is not installed, the link below provides the tutorial for download.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5l9ud","text":"\nhttps://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":1,"length":42}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"B1E5DC269E9911EE885E0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop"}}}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"clq4o","text":"The Medication Possession Ratio (MPR) provides an estimate of patient adherence based on the actual possession of medications. It is a metric that offers crucial information to assist in the development of strategies for the proper management of chronic diseases, such as Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML). RStudio is a free, open-source software maintained by an active community of developers, ensuring frequent updates and specialized packages in the healthcare domain. This software can be easily integrated into the practices of healthcare professionals for MPR calculations, optimizing their activities and allowing more time for direct patient care. In this context, a protocol was developed using the R programming language for MPR calculation, utilizing a spreadsheet with Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitor dispensation data. This script provides flexibility for MPR calculations to be applied to any chronic disease.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bt4qu","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6m9bb","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
keywords: Patient Compliance, Chronic Disease, Leukemia Myeloid Chronic-Phase
protocol_references:
{"blocks":[{"key":"nu6f","text":"Andrade, K.H. Kahler, F. Frech, and K. A. Chan, “Methods for evaluation of medication
adherence and persistence using automated databases,” Pharmacoepidemiology andDrug Safety, vol. 15, no. 8, pp. 565–574, 2006.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3gh0t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dhtfr","text":"R CORE TEAM. R: A language and environment for statistical computing. R Foundation for
Statistical Computing. 2022 Vienna, Austria","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cja3b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"79s4c","text":"TAN, B.K. et al. Monitoring and Improving Adherence to Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitors in
Patients with Chronic Myeloid Leukemia: A Systematic Review. Patient Prefer
Adherence, v. 18, n. 15, p. 2563 -2575, 2021.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

status.info: We use this protocol and it's working

steps.step:
{"blocks":[{"key":"458l5","text":"Every time you open the software, you should load the following
packages:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dc6tp","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"41egp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"","description":"","guid":"3768C8CA9E7D11EE885E0A58A9FEAC02","name":"library(tidyverse)   # Loads the Tidyverse, a collection of packages for data manipulation and visualization, including popular packages like dplyr and ggplot2.
library(openxlsx)    # Loads the openxlsx library, which is used for spreadsheet manipulation and working with Excel files.
library(psych)       # Loads the psych library, providing functions for statistical analysis and psychometrics.
library(gtsummary)   # Loads the gtsummary library, used for creating summary tables in a concise and elegant manner.
library(flextable)   # Loads the flextable library, providing a flexible approach to creating tables with various formatting options.
library(magrittr)    # Loads the magrittr library, facilitating data manipulation using the pipe operator %>%. The pipe operator is used to chain operations together in a readable and efficient way.
","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

steps.section: Setting the working directory to a specific path
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"4a2ob","text":"Setting the working directory is important because it determines the default location for reading and writing files.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"adc02","text":"1-    In RStudio, go to the \"Session\" menu.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ag68b","text":"2-    Select \"Set Working Directory\" and choose \"Choose Directory...\"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2kuo5","text":"3-    Navigate to the directory","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2aom3","text":"# Alternatively, you can use the command below:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bkdpn","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"81ole","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"","description":"","guid":"F12C2CB29E7D11EE885E0A58A9FEAC02","name":"Setwd ( \"C:/Path/To/Your/Directory\") #put the path of your directory inside the parenthesis","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5pcpd","text":"# Here we read the data file called "file­.mpr." and store it in a variable called MPR.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4g46o","text":"# The read.csv2 function is used to read data from a CSV file where the column separator is a semicolon (;).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"10jcf","text":"# The argument "file.mpr" represents the name of the file to be read. You should download the spreadsheet with the medication dispensation data from your institution's dispensation system. In
this example, the obtained spreadsheet contains: Medication name, number of
dispensed units, and patient medical record number. We chose to use the medical
record number to avoid homonyms.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"50mko","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"efq5","text":"# Now, the variable MPR contains the data from the CSV file, and you can manipulate or perform additional analyses as needed.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"","description":"","guid":"E6DA3FB39E8111EE885E0A58A9FEAC02","name":"MPR <- read.csv2("file.mpr.csv") #Add .csv after the file name","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"lo34","text":"Now, we select the columns that are relevant to our analysis and store them in a new variable called MPR1.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cs5jn","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7m9gu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"","description":"","guid":"8AB0F7479E8611EE885E0A58A9FEAC02","name":"MPR1 \u003c- MPR %\u003e%\n  select(Drug, Dispensed, Medical.record)\n","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dn3ja","text":"We use the \"glimpse\" command to visualize the structure of our MPR1 dataset.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bkfi8","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"duoft","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"","description":"","guid":"B77F1A709E8611EE885E0A58A9FEAC02","name":"glimpse(MPR1)","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ahemn","text":"In this step, we convert the by \"Medical.record\" column into characters to ensure it is handled correctly.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4g8go","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6saj1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"djmt5","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"","description":"","guid":"A55A2BDB9E8711EE885E0A58A9FEAC02","name":"MPR1$Medical.record \u003c- as.character(MPR1$Medical.record)","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b6uge","text":" We perform calculations in the "Dispensed" column based on the conditions specified for each
"drug".","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9mcba","text":"We also group the data by "Medical.record "and "drug" and calculate the percentagem.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"16dj0","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6o7sn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"","description":"","guid":"BAE9F1D69E8811EE885E0A58A9FEAC02","name":"MPR1 <- MPR1 %>%
  mutate(
    Dispensed = Dispensed / 365,  #calculation for a period of 1 year)
    Dispensed = case_when(
      Drug == "Imatinibe 100mg" ~ Dispensed / 2,#referring to two tablets per day. In the case of 3 tablets, divide by 3, and so on.
      Drug == "Dasatinibe 20mg" ~ Dispensed / 2,
      Drug == "Nilotinibe 200mg" ~ Dispensed / 4,
      Drug == "Imatinibe 400mg" ~ Dispensed,
      Drug == "Dasatinibe 100mg" ~ Dispensed
    )
  ) %>%
  group_by(Medical.record, Drug) %>%
  summarise(
    Porcentagem = ifelse(sum(Dispensed) > 100, 100, round(sum(Dispensed), 2) * 100),
    .groups = "drop"  
  ) %>%
  mutate(Porcentagem = ifelse(Porcentagem > 100, 100, Porcentagem),
         Porcentagem = format(Porcentagem, digits = 2, nsmall = 2, scientific = FALSE) %>%
           paste0("%"))

","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"epofk","text":"Here we create a flexible table (ft) and adjust its properties such as width and alignment.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1fvj7","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"epm9d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"","description":"","guid":"7AC115589E8B11EE885E0A58A9FEAC02","name":"ft <- flextable(MPR1)
set_table_properties(ft,
                    width = 0.99,
                    align = "center")  #Aligns the table contents to the center.
","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"31u8u","text":" Finally, we save the document with the name \"MPR_Percentagem.docx\" in the specified location.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"34osr","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"agovg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"","description":"","guid":"ADC334609E8B11EE885E0A58A9FEAC02","name":"save_as_docx(ft, path = \"C:/Path/To/Your/Directory/MPR_Percentagem.docx\") #put the path of your directory inside the parenthesis","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fbn8e","text":"In the specific context of this script, the section "Installing the packages" is dedicated to
installing additional packages that are necessary to execute the subsequent analyses. Each line install.packages("package_name") installs a specific package. Press Ctrl + Enter to run the code. The
code is as follows:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aq0qm","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9s7rt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"","description":"","guid":"023B72C39EA311EE885E0A58A9FEAC02","name":"install.packages("tidyverse")
install.packages("openxlsx")
install.packages("psych")
install.packages("gtsummary")
install.packages("flextable")
install.packages("magrittr")
","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}
